info.game_comments:
Andrew Bernknopf game 1.
Final Jeopardy! Round incomplete.

(1, 1).clue: In botany it's the term used for the liquid in the stems & roots of plants & trees

(2, 1).clue: On Sept. 30, 1927 Washington's Tom Zachary threw the pitch that became this man's 60th homer of the season

(3, 1).clue: The American version of the British "Johnny Newcome"

(4, 1).clue: Some Biblical scholars believe it was an orange or a quince--or possibly an apricot

(5, 1).clue: As president of the Senate, on Jan. 4, 1989 he announced to Congress that George Bush won the election

(6, 1).clue: Eric Knight died while serving in WWII, just 4 years after writing the story of this collie

(1, 2).clue: This bacterium is responsible for many infections including strep throat & scarlet fever

(2, 2).clue: H.L. Mencken said his chief feat "was to sleep more than any other president"

(3, 2).clue: Term for something that's different or unusual, not on the well-worn path

(4, 2).clue: Governor of Judea who asked Jesus, "Art thou the king of the Jews?"

(5, 2).clue: Incumbent David Durenberger defeated Hubert Humphrey III in this state's 1988 Senate race

(6, 2).clue: Name shared by the 3 billy goats who met up with the wicked old troll

(1, 3).clue: The smallest of all constellations is Crux, also known by this name

(2, 3).clue: Among this jazz bandleader's recorded hits were "King Porter Stomp" & "The Jelly Roll Blues"

(3, 3).clue: A person or thing that comes at the end of a list but is nonetheless important

(4, 3).clue: A ladder reaching to heaven appeared to him in a dream

(5, 3).clue: The first Speaker of the House, Frederick Muhlenberg, was a member of this party

(6, 3).clue: His stories include "Brer Mink Holds His Breath" & "Brer Buzzard & The Tombstone"

(1, 4).clue: From the Greek for "earthquake writer", this instrument records any Earth movement

(2, 4).clue: A flapper was a girl & a flivver one of these

(3, 4).clue: Phrase meaning "wish me luck", from the old superstition of making the sign of the cross to ward off evil

(4, 4).clue: God first appeared to Moses in this form

(5, 4).clue: He was Wyoming's U.S. representative & GOP House Whip when he was nominated for Sec'y of Defense

(6, 4).clue: Willie Wonka owned the world's most famous one

(1, 5).clue: This bluish glow is sometimes seen at the tips of tall objects during thunderstorms

(2, 5).clue: Pop psychologist Emile Coue promoted the motto, "Every day, in every way, I am" doing this

(3, 5).clue: From a magician's trick, it means to accomplish the unexpected or find a surprising solution
(3, 5).correct response: pull a rabbit out of a hat

(4, 5).clue: The first verse of the book of Proverbs attributes its authorship to this man

(5, 5).clue: The Rockefeller who's a Senator from West Virginia

(6, 5).clue: The profession of Nancy Drew's father

(1, 1).clue: In a 1956 speech, he said, "Whether or not you like it, history is on our side.  We will bury you."

(2, 1).clue: Tom Hanks got the starring role in this "huge" film after Robert De Niro turned it down

(3, 1).clue: Hadrian's Wall is in England; Hadrian's Tomb is in this city

(4, 1).clue: Departments of this media magazine include "Soaps", "Grapevine" & "Videocassette Report"

(5, 1).clue: This "Threepenny Opera" composer studied with Engelbert Humperdinck--the composer, not the singer

(6, 1).clue: Emmissions of nitrogen & sulfur oxides into the air cause this, endangering fish & aquatic life

(1, 2).clue: Alfred E. Smith said, "All the ills of democracy can be cured by more" of this

(2, 2).clue: The great 19th c. actor Edwin Booth was most famous for playing this Shakespearean role

(3, 2).clue: The chief port in Australia's Northern Territory; it was named after a naturalist on the Beagle

(4, 2).clue: This magazine, the first undergraduate humor magazine in the U.S., was begun at Harvard in 1876

(5, 2).clue: Great Broadway composer who wrote the music for the documentary series "Victory at Sea"

(6, 2).clue: In 1985 French military advisors at Auckland, New Zealand sank this group's vessel, the Rainbow Warrior

(1, 3).clue: This great Prussian king is credited with saying, "An army, like a serpent, travels on its belly"

(2, 3).clue: "Dallas" actor heard here singing in a 1953 movie musical:"Where is the light that's lit by land?  Where is it now?"

(3, 3).clue: The 1759 British victory on the Plains of Abraham at this city helped them conquer Canada

(4, 3).clue: In addition to Penthouse, Bob Guccione owns this magazine of science & futurism

(5, 3).clue: Borodin, the illegitimate son of a Russian prince, died before finishing his opera about this prince

(6, 3).clue: This device added to a car's exhaust system eliminates much of the pollution produced by gas combustion

(1, 4).clue: Asked after the Constitutional Convention "What have we got?", he replied "A republic, if you can keep it"

(2, 4).clue: He was the first actor to win an Oscar & a Tony for the same role, for "Cyrano de Bergerac"

(3, 4).clue: It's the only city on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands

(4, 4).clue: In 1981 Budget Dir. Stockman's criticism of the Reagan administration was published in this monthly

(5, 4).clue: Rossini called this composer of "Gaite Parisienne" "Our little Mozart of the Champs-Elysees"

(6, 4).clue: It's said various medical problems have resulted from toxins dumped in this part of Niagara Falls, N.Y.

(1, 5).clue: When Napoleon said "England is a nation of shopkeepers", he was quoting this economist

(2, 5).clue: He was Ingrid Bergman's leading man in her 1st American film, "Intermezzo"

(3, 5).clue: This city is the eastern terminus of the Trans-Siberian Railway & home to the Soviet Pacific fleet

(4, 5).clue: Since 1912 this federation of businesses has published its own monthly magazine, Nation's Business

(5, 5).clue: Trained as an engineer, this Hungarian composed the operettas "The Desert Song" & "The New Moon"

(6, 5).clue: In 1978 the U.S. banned use of these, called CFCs for short, as propellants in most spray cans

(0, 0).clue: After his death in 1745, he was buried in St. Patrick's cathedral in Dublin
